forecast.no_outcome_scenario: The 2021 India–Pakistan ceasefire largely holds. Any flare-ups remain confined to the LoC/AJK areas (which do not count) or are non-kinetic. No mass-casualty terror attack in India traceable to Pakistan-based groups occurs, so Delhi sees no need to authorize punitive action into Pakistan proper. Routine border frictions (e.g., drones, smuggling, small-arms fire) do not escalate, and any firing that occurs along the international border is by the BSF (not the Armed Forces), thus not qualifying.
forecast.yes_outcome_scenario: A high-casualty terror attack inside India in late May or June is credibly linked to Pakistan-based militants, prompting the Cabinet Committee on Security to authorize a limited punitive strike. The IAF conducts a Balakot-style air/missile/drone strike on a target in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, or the Army executes precision fires into Pakistani Punjab across the Working Boundary (and is clearly identified as the actor). Alternatively, India targets a militant facility in Sindh or Balochistan with standoff weapons. The action is reported credibly and attributable to the Indian Armed Forces.
forecast.rationale:
Baseline and incentives: Cross-border kinetic strikes by India into Pakistan proper are rare; the salient modern precedent is the IAF’s February 2019 Balakot strike in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa. Most India–Pakistan violence occurs along the LoC/AKJ and would not count here. Nuclear risk and international pressure strongly discourage Indian operations deep inside Pakistan absent a major provocation. The political incentive for a June 2025 strike is modest without a triggering event; there is no immediate national election driver, and both sides typically prefer to avoid uncontrolled escalation. 

Definition tightness: The question requires the attack to hit Sindh, Balochistan, Punjab, or Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and be executed by the Indian Armed Forces (Army, Navy, Air Force). This excludes: (1) incidents in Pakistan-administered Kashmir (where most kinetic exchanges occur), and (2) cross-border firing by the BSF along the international border, since BSF is not part of the Armed Forces. These constraints materially lower odds. 

Base-rate framing: Since 2016 there has been one widely acknowledged strike in Pakistan proper (2019). That suggests a low annual base rate. Mapping that to a single-month window absent clear triggers implies a single-digit probability. 

Escalation channels: The main pathway to a Yes is a large, widely attributed terror attack in India prompting a limited, reputationally important strike (likely IAF) into KP or a precision standoff strike into Punjab/Sindh. Without such a shock, the status quo (No) is favored. Weather/operational considerations (early monsoon cloud cover by late June) mildly complicate air ops, further nudging odds down at the margin. 

Why not higher: No specific trigger is known; the definitional exclusions (AKJ incidents, BSF fire) remove many common escalations; and the political/military costs of striking Pakistan proper remain high. 

Why not lower: India has demonstrated willingness and capability (Balakot 2019) to conduct punitive strikes into KP. If a major terror incident occurs, a limited kinetic response in Pakistan proper within days is plausible. The existence of persistent militancy and periodic infiltration attempts keeps a non-zero tail risk. 

What would move me up: Credible reports of a mass-casualty terror attack in India attributed to Pakistan-based groups; emergency meetings of India’s CCS; unusual IAF forward deployments/NOTAMs near the border; public threats of retaliation from senior Indian officials; cross-border airspace closures; evacuation advisories for Indian border districts; a marked spike in ceasefire violations along the Working Boundary. 

What would move me down: Signals of de-escalation or backchannel engagement; reaffirmed ceasefire statements; a quiet first half of June with no serious incidents; diplomatic pressure/messages from major powers urging restraint; evidence that any border incidents are confined to AJK/LoC or involve only the BSF.
